segments.text: international students, and you said Saudi Arabia students were not quite as good.
Well, it depended on where they were, you know, what their status was in the society.
The ones who were in a high status, they felt that they didn't have to do anything.
Everybody had to do everything for them, even including their research work, and other ones were very hardworking.
They were generally fairly intelligent.
The ones that we had from Turkey would work very hard, but their quality seemed to be a lot lower, even than the Saudi Arabia.
More often than not, did these students come with an undergraduate degree?
Yes.
They came as graduate students?
Correct.
Where had they done their undergraduate degree?
Mostly in the national universities.
In their country?
In their own country.
In terms of their family backgrounds, were they by and large from families that had the parents had a college degree?
I don't remember whether they did or not.

I suspect they did, but they came from families that were better off, well off, relatively well off, and also who were interested in education, as you might expect, because they did have to sort of pay for their coming over here.
They would not be what we would call peasant families.
No.
Definitely not.
Did ever have any that you can remember who were from very well-to-do and or families with royal blood?
Did you all ever have any of those?
I'm not sure we had any with royal blood, but we did have some that were well-to-do, that looked like they had more money and they knew what to do with.
And especially that Saudi Arabian student in particular, I think he had from a well-to-do family, which was indicative of his work ethic.
Now, I remember in the late 70s when I was dean of faculties, we worked with the Saudi Arabian government to make a kind of a package deal in a number of departments.
Did you all ever have a kind of a contract with any nation or any government about that?
Not in the beginning.
It may have in the recent past.
There may have been some.
And with Saudi Arabia.
I think when Terry Spencer and Joel Watkins set up the petroleum geology or petroleum geophysics program, I think they may have set up something with China and with Saudi Arabia.
Right now, back in the 70s, President Williams is followed by Jarvis Miller.
Did his presidency have any impact on y'all?
No.
Right.
Then Frank Vandiver.
Right.
Any presidents coming through the 80s and 90s that you recall having a direct impact on how y'all did things?
No, they didn't do anything bad.
They didn't do anything good.
We were sort of off in our own little corner, and I don't think they helped us or hurt us.
All right, trace on through then the department heads in geophysics.
Well, let's see.
After Earl Hoskins, then I got Joel Watkins, I believe.
And after Joel, why, now we've got Andy Hash.
How long has he been here?
Andy was an undergraduate, a graduate student here, so he's been here since the 70s.
Did he stay?
He never left?
That's right, he never left.
My goodness.
So he did all his degrees here.
Well, I'm not sure he did the undergraduate degree.
He certainly did the graduate degree.
It was in geology, not in geophysics.
All right, then the deans.
What about the deans that made a difference?
Well, I think the only one, well, let's see.
Mel Friedman made somewhat of a difference because there was a time when things were tough in the oil business.
And Mel got kind of hustling around with the Department of Energy to kind of get us into that program to try to improve matters there.
We got into the nuclear waste isolation and stuff like that.
I remember Gordy Eaton, who preceded Mell, was a very effective dean, because he was such a good organizer and operator and personable and so forth, and seemed to do a very nice job.
His interaction with the department wasn't quite as much as it was as Mell, because Mell had already been in the department.
And so he already knew who the department was.
And so we got along quite well.
He had an impact.
And after him, after Mel, I guess, was Deuce.
I believe, and after Deuce is Pryor.
I think those guys have done about as much as the presidents have done.
They just didn't make any difference.
In terms of the college, oceanography, meteorology, geology, geophysics, and geography, has the college down through your 30-some odd years seemed to pull together reasonably well?
No, I really don't think so.
As a matter of fact, I think one of the really dumbest moves that was ever made was that they built the oceanography and meteorology building so far away from this building.
And so consequently, there's been very little interaction between meteorology and geophysics, or oceanography and geophysics.
and between geography and geophysics.
Well, geography maybe is not so bad.
Maybe there doesn't should be, or there isn't much reason to have much interaction.
But there hasn't been any with that.
So no, I don't think it's really pulled together.
I think it's the lack of propinquity that's caused the real problem.
And I think it's a bad move, whoever decided to do that.
And I think they did that because they wanted that stupid weather radar on the top of the thing there, and they were afraid of this water tower.
But that was a bad move.
Also, going to a tall building is a bad move.
I was at MIT when they did the I.M.
Pei building, the green building there.
And it was a very small base and very tall.
You got almost no communication from one floor to the next.
It's almost like the laws of physics are here.
The greater the potential, the less the interaction.
It's inversely proportional to the distance and the height.
And interaction between the faculty is a very important and crucial thing.
This building is great because it's long, very long, and only three stories high or so, and that's the way it should be.
I'm nodding my head in agreement because I believe that we human beings don't move vertically nearly as well as we move horizontally.
Correct.
uh... university of texas library towers uh... notable example of that uh... the uh... washington monument is a good visual symbol but that's all yeah that's all
Do you recall, looking back over these 30 years, do you recall when the department and or the college might have gone after some research grant or some project that it didn't?
That it didn't get?
Was there some opportunity that either it tried and failed or didn't even make an effort?
Well, we went after a lot of things, and we tried.
Some we were successful, some we failed.
But I don't think there was anything that was so traumatic that it knocked us to our knees or anything like that.
We could have done better than we did do in terms of getting research work.
I don't think we went after as much as we should have.
Can you think of some geophysics research accomplishment when that really began to put this department on the map, began to clearly demonstrate it was playing in the big leagues?
That's a good question.
That's tough to answer, because the only ones I can think of are the ones that I did.
And I'm not sure that's fair to say that.
No, I really can't think of anything.
Well, I guess maybe the SALT project, the nuclear waste project.
and nuclear isolation in the SALT project, which was partly in this department and also in geology in the Center for Tectonal Physics.
But the Center for Tectonal Physics always was a very important part.
I think the Center for Tectonal Physics put this department on the map, or this college or this group on the map, because of the many diverse things that they did and useful things that they did.
Which ones in particular specifically?
I can't think of all of them.
Are there some national rankings, national listings of the top five or ten geophysics?
Are those ever done?
I think they are.
I don't know what our rank is.
You don't know where?
We've never been in the top five.
But we would be, if someone asked us where we big league, we'd claim that, wouldn't we?
Yeah, right.
But second tier.
Top ten?
Top ten, probably.
Certainly top 20, yeah.
The involvement with industry, is it today about what it used to be?
What are the current trends in research and job placement today?

Actually, I think the involvement in research is even more today than it was in the past, mostly because the oil companies themselves have gotten rid of their research departments and so therefore they're doing a lot of stuff outside with the universities, with consortia.
So in that sense, I think it's increased.
However, the oil companies have
Their total effort has gone down all the way along the line.
They seem to be pulling in their ears.
The oil companies are being run more by businessmen than they are by engineers or geologists or people who are interested in the business.
There seems to be less interest in the actual nuts and bolts of the business and more interest in how much money can they make and so forth.
I think the oil companies, if they're not careful, are going to cause their own destruction by that attitude.
With the mergers and so forth, they've cut back on the scholarships they've given us, as far as I know.
I don't really know, though.
The department head would have to tell you that.
But my impression is that there's much less.
Well, then I guess we've dropped the ball a good bit, too.
There was a time when we would have almost one half of all the scholarships that were given by the Society of Exploration Geophysicists.
I don't think we have one or two of them now.
And that was at a time when they would give out 10 or 20.
And now they're giving out 30 or 40, and we don't have but maybe one or two.
And I think that's our fault, not going after these, number one.
Number two, not having the quality of students that we used to have in the past.
But it really was people working at it.
Now, as the female enrollment here grew, did women coming to take courses in geophysics cause any changes in the way you all did things?
No.
Do you remember any kind of awkward incidents or moments when somebody told a joke or a story that they had been telling to an all-male audience and it didn't go over well?
Well, there were some of those, yeah, right.
I don't remember any one in specific, but I do remember in general that there were times when stuff like that would happen.
But generally, the Aggies are good people.
They're well-behaved, well-mannered young men.
And they would never give the girls a bad time.
They might needle them a little bit, but it was always in good humor.
I would never try to embarrass them.
I don't ever remember that happening.

Sometimes the girls would get embarrassed because they would say something because just in their natural youthful exuberance, they would say something that if the girls hadn't been there, it would have been OK.
But because the girls were there, it wasn't OK.
But that ended up fairly quickly because of the fact that the female enrollment built up quite strongly, very quickly in geophysics.
And so there were always females around.
women students.
So, yeah, how to behave yourself, you know.
And besides, it was just, that was the Texan stuff, the good manners of the Texan stuff anyway.
Did you have any particular classroom or laboratory guidelines that you made clear to the students, what they were to do and not to do?
Yeah, I told them that when they came on in, Texas A&M had the policy that the students were required to attend classes.
I told them that I felt that they were adults and that that was really not necessary.
I told them that I would take the role for the first two weeks.
And I said, the reason why I would take roll for the first two weeks was so that I could put a name with the face.
And after that, I wouldn't need it anymore.
I actually didn't even need it for two weeks.
I said, whether they came or not was up to them.
I told them that my purpose of being there was to teach them.
And if they could learn the subject without coming to class, that was fine by me.
All they had to do is know when the exams were, be there on time, get their homework in, get it in on time.
And that they didn't need to be there to gratify my ego, that they would make me feel good, make my ego feel good if they got good scores on the exam.
So that was the way in which I played it.
I very rarely had kids not go to class at the same time.
Mostly because I think I taught them some things during the lecture as well.
Did you ever have any less than credible excuses for missing a test or an absence of any sort?
Well, not on absences because I never asked for... No, but I mean maybe because they missed something and they tried to explain why they weren't there.
Oh, no, no, because if there were, I wouldn't remember them because I'd say, it doesn't matter to me.
You want to come, you come, you didn't come.
If you didn't come, it's your responsibility to go find out what happened during the class and to make up for it.
It felt like I were treating them as adults, and I expected them to understand what was going on and to take care of it.
They were past 18, well all of them were 20, 21 years old.
They were seniors, juniors and seniors.
I saw no reason to treat them as children and did not.
The best one I ever had was the student who came up very seriously the first day to tell me about his grandfather's illness.
and that it apparently was terminal.
And I began to feel very sorry for him.
And he told me that, in fact, it was almost certain that his grandfather would die the first day of deer season.
And he wanted me to know that in advance.
And he was a deer hunter.
Yeah, and we both chuckled over that.
Did you get one for me, did you say?
Let's see.
More departmental.
Do you remember any departmental crises
where y'all were felt up against the wall on a budget matter or a vacancy at the last moment in a faculty or something like that?
No.
No crises of that sort?
I don't think so.
No, there's nothing that we couldn't handle.
You know, you expect things to come up.
We haven't had any natural disasters where the building... No.
Over the years, has the space for offices, labs, and lectures been reasonably adequate?
Oh yeah, plenty adequate.
As a matter of fact, I personally think there's a lot of wasted space at this university, but don't quote me on that.
In fact, more adequacy than parking.
Yeah, right, right, yes.
Let's see.
Describe your work with graduate students, theses and dissertations.
You must over the years have produced a number of those.
Yeah, I'd have about 10 PhDs.
Usually they would come on in and they'd say, well, we want to work on a problem.
And sometimes some of them would have an idea of what they wanted to do, but generally they didn't.
I generally had three or four topics that I thought needed to be done, and I would suggest them to them.
Also, in the classes that I taught, I required all the students to do a term paper.
And I gave them a bunch of topics from which to pick, and also they gave a presentation as well.
And a lot of them took those presentations and used those for dissertation topics.
So that's the way it ended, and we kind of worked together at it.
I'm not sure we ever published any on these things.
Of course, we've been pretty bad.
My students have been pretty bad about publishing.
I've been pretty bad about publishing, too.
As a matter of fact, one of the things I'm hoping during my retirement to do is publish some of the dissertations that my students have done jointly with them, of course, you realize.
But we generally work very closely together.
I've always felt that you can teach people to be creative.
I think there's a very definite technique for doing it.
To do dissertation type work, there has to be a creative aspect to it.
But I don't think it's impossible.
I don't think there's a big deal to it.
And I think I eventually got the kids to the point where they, too, became creative.
Or they would start making ideas and making suggestions.
I'd say, hey, why don't we do this?
Yeah, OK. And that was just fine.
Of course, part of it might have been that they were maturing and building up their background.
And it's very hard to be creative without having any ability.
Most of these theses and dissertations, are they in the same general area?
Topic area?
No, not really.
They're kind of diverse, just like my is the diverse.
Different areas.
One is involved.
One area would be data processing.
Another area would be seismic wave propagation.
Another area are rock properties.
Let's see, the other is this physics of the earth kind of thing.
Of which of these graduate student theses and dissertations, of which are you most proud as you reflect in hindsight?
Yeah, that's a good question.
I think Jean-Claude Marchal's dissertation is the one that I'm the proudest of.
And that's the one where he did take this Moho stuff and he did some calculations on it.
But I've had a couple of other students who did some really nice stuff.
Some of it was pretty practical, like Buck Behan.
He did one on adaptive data processing, which is an area that I've been interested in a long time.
And Dan Hines did some stuff on the deformation of rocks, looking at them under a microscope, which I thought was very interesting.
Also correlation technique and data processing involved in that.
So there have been half a dozen or so that were really quite good.
I've been proud of most of my PhDs.
Well, I'm proud of all of them, all the PhD students.
Master's students, maybe some of them got by with all the PhDs.
did solid work, as far as I'm concerned.
In the department, who are some, were the key staff members during the years working in the departmental offices and so forth?
Who were some people that deserve a pat on the back?
Well, certainly Anita Ficke was one.
She worked with the Underburger first and then became part of the department.
And Michelle, who's now down in the geology office, Michelle Beale, she has been very useful.
There was Linda, oh, gee, it was a redhead.
Oh, gosh, what's her name?
Oh.
I can't remember.
I can see her face, but I can't remember her name.
The Alzheimer's are going to get to me, I guess.
But she was very, very important and very effective.
She was the secretary when I was the acting head, and she was very important, very effective.
Some of the others that we've had, there was another gal named Linda who was pretty good, but some of them actually were, well, they were there, but they weren't really much use.
Do you remember any important decisions made elsewhere on campus that had a big impact on the department?
No, I don't think so.
Were there any state decisions, legislature, governor, coordinating board?
No, I really don't think so.
More recently there may be the business about limiting the number of hours that students can take, but that's a recent thing, and the graduate programs.
Actually, they always seemed to have made a very good environment for us to do what we wanted to do.
It was kind of up to us to do something.
And the state of Texas and Texas A&M have been reasonably competitive in salaries and scholarship offers and things like that?
In scholarship offers, yes.
I think that we've had people who've been very generous to the university.
I don't think the university itself has been very competitive in terms of salaries.
Is that right?
Yeah.
I know my own salary has been pretty poor and would have been glad to have made a move if I could have, but didn't have the opportunity.
If you could be the czar,
Which geophysics programs nationally would you today hold out as models of quality that A&M should try to equal or surpass?
I would say MIT, Caltech, UCLA are amongst the top ones.
Are there any others that are really high?
Berkeley's pretty good.
Yeah.
And Stanford.
And Rice is getting a pretty good program.
If you, all right, are there any changes if you had an unlimited budget?
And again, you were czar of the department.
Are there any changes you would make in the department today?
What I'm really asking is what advice, if you were called upon as the consultant, what course of action would you advise the department to undertake today?
I would rather not say anything about that question.
Getting near the end of the questions I can think of, who is there that you would like to thank for these 30 plus years here?
Oh, well, I think I'd like to thank the state and the university because it's been a nice environment.
I've enjoyed it.
So I don't really feel like the people, Earl Cook made me feel comfortable and welcome.
So did Horace Byers.
Department heads, I'm not sure that I really got along all that well with any of them.
Earl Hoskins was probably the one that I got along best with.
Of course, I have a hard time getting along with people anyway.
It's part of my problem, but that's my problem, not theirs.
Can I think of anybody else who really made it a great place to be?
Well, I've enjoyed having Bob Berg around.
I spent time talking with him, learned a good bit of geology from him, and perhaps learned how to survive a little better in academia because of him as well.
Anybody else that I can think of?
No.
Well, John Hand had an influence also.
John was a very strong person and a very good organizer and good scientist and knew how to do things.
And I always admired and enjoyed having him.
And he always treated me fairly, I thought.
Well, let's see.
If you have any A&M related materials and you ever want to dispose of them, I would beg you please call the A&M archives because they would organize them and maintain them, particularly
any memorabilia about the institution.
Okay, like the photographs.
That kind of thing.
Oh, yes, yes, yes.
Grade books.
Okay.
Evaluations of the department and that sort of thing.
Okay.
All right.
Next, the last question.
Okay.
If someone gave you a million dollar check,
with one requirement, that you give it to Texas A&M and you decide what use would be made of it, if you had a large sum of money you could pass on to A&M, what would you want it used for?
I think I'd use it for scholarships, undergraduate, graduate scholarships for those students interested in theoretical geophysics.
A million dollars is a lot of money, however.
How would you identify the students?
Who gets the scholarship?
Well, it would depend on, first of all, their interest.
They'd have to have an interest in doing theoretical stuff.
They'd have to show an ability to do it, which means that they'd have to have a good background in math and physics and geology and an interest in the field.
So you'd make it ability-based, talent-based.

primarily yeah right yeah I think because you can get the ability most anywhere you know I was certainly wouldn't do it racially or you wouldn't do it on a need basis financial need as much as ability
Well, I would rather it went to somebody who needed it, but at the same time, I would presume that whoever's asking for it does need it.
Otherwise, if they don't need it, I would say, hey, don't take it.
Clearly, yeah, right.
Need should be a consideration, but not the most important consideration.
I wouldn't give it to a bad needy student, let a good, not so needy student go by.
Last question.
What feelings do you have in your heart today about Texas A&M?
Oh, I think it was a great place.
It was a good place to be.
I spent a lot of my life here.
I think I could have been treated better.
I think my contributions could have been recognized better.
And the salary really wasn't very important, per se, because I got more money than I know what to do with now, even with the salary that I had, which wasn't very good.
But the fact is that there were other people who were getting salaries that were much more than mine.
And I felt their contributions to the university weren't equal to mine.
And that sort of bothered me more.
I would rather they had cut the other guy's salary.
